body:
Hi @stanos4 ,
I am not sure what you mean. I just started a training session with a CSV hook, which interrupted after some epochs. When I started the same script again, it continued at the same point where I interrupted it without any errors. Did you run the scripts, or did you use your own code?

I practically use the tutorial only, here are the steps (I just modified some cutoffs and batch sizes to see if I can increase my GPU utilization). But I'm running on Windows10 machine now, with the conda version of Schnetpack (conda install -c conda-forge schnetpack):


    
    import schnetpack as spk
    from schnetpack.datasets import QM9
    from torch.optim import Adam
    import schnetpack.train as trn
    import numpy as np
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    from ase.units import kcal, mol
    import torch
    import time
    import os
    
    def mse_loss(batch, result):
        diff = batch[QM9.U0] - result[QM9.U0]
        err_sq = torch.mean(diff**2)
        return err_sq
    
    
    qm9tut = os.getcwd()
    environment_provider = spk.environment.TorchEnvironmentProvider(device='cuda', cutoff=8.0)
    qm9data = QM9('qm9.db', download=False, load_only=[QM9.U0], remove_uncharacterized=True)
    train, val, test = spk.train_test_split(data=qm9data, num_train=10000, num_val=500, 
    split_file=os.path.join(qm9tut, "split.npz"))
    train_loader = spk.AtomsLoader(val, batch_size=80, shuffle=True)
    val_loader = spk.AtomsLoader(val, batch_size=80)
    atomrefs = qm9data.get_atomref(QM9.U0)
    means, stddevs = train_loader.get_statistics(QM9.U0, divide_by_atoms=True, 
    single_atom_ref=atomrefs)
    print(means, stddevs)
    schnet = spk.representation.SchNet(n_atom_basis=30, n_filters=30, n_gaussians=20, 
    n_interactions=5, cutoff=8., cutoff_network=spk.nn.cutoff.CosineCutoff)
    output_U0 = spk.atomistic.Atomwise(n_in=30, atomref=atomrefs[QM9.U0], property=QM9.U0, 
    mean=means[QM9.U0], stddev=stddevs[QM9.U0])
    
    model = spk.AtomisticModel(representation=schnet, output_modules=output_U0)
    optimizer = Adam(model.parameters(), lr=1e-2)
    
    loss = trn.build_mse_loss([QM9.U0])
    metrics = [spk.metrics.MeanAbsoluteError(QM9.U0)]
    hooks = [trn.CSVHook(log_path=qm9tut, metrics=metrics), 
    trn.ReduceLROnPlateauHook(optimizer, patience=5, factor=0.8, min_lr=1e-6, stop_after_min=True)]
    
    trainer = trn.Trainer(model_path=qm9tut, model=model, hooks=hooks, loss_fn=loss, 
    optimizer=optimizer, train_loader=train_loader, validation_loader=val_loader,checkpoint_interval=40, validation_interval=5)
    
    device = "cuda"
    #device = "cpu"
    n_epochs = 300
    trainer.train(device=device, n_epochs=n_epochs)


then it's enough to rerun the last command and it will crash in my case.

Also, yesterday I tested on another machine, linux this time (fedora 31 with cuda as well) and I can see that the csv log file is different. On windows, I get an empty line after each log record, on linux it's without the empty lines.
Oh, ok. Could you maybe also add the error message and the csv file?

attached is the log and here is the error message:

    >>> trainer.train(device=device, n_epochs=n_epochs)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "C:\Users\XXX\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python37\site-packages\schnetpack\train\trainer.py", line 163, in train
        h.on_train_begin(self)
      File "C:\Users\XXX\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python37\site-packages\schnetpack\train\hooks\logging.py", line 115, in on_train_begin
        self._offset = float(lines[-1].split(",")[0]) - time.time()
    ValueError: could not convert string to float:


[log.txt](https://github.com/atomistic-machine-learning/schnetpack/files/3911375/log.txt)

Hi @stanos4 ,

Could you maybe try and run these lines on Windows and send me the resulting log files?

```
import os
with open("log_test_0.csv", "a+") as f:
  f.write("test test test" + os.linesep)
with open("log_test_0.csv", "a+") as f:
  f.write("test test test" + os.linesep)
```

and 

```
import os
with open("log_test_1.csv", "a+", newline="") as f:
  f.write("test test test" + os.linesep)
with open("log_test_1.csv", "a+", newline="") as f:
  f.write("test test test" + os.linesep)
```

I can not test on Windows, but maybe this already solves the problem.
Thanks!

sorry, but nope, still the same (I modified my source according to your patch).

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "C:\Users\ssimko\AppData\Local\Continuum\miniconda3\envs\schn\lib\site-packages\schnetpack\train\trainer.py", line 160, in train
        h.on_train_begin(self)
      File "C:\Users\ssimko\AppData\Local\Continuum\miniconda3\envs\schn\lib\site-packages\schnetpack\train\hooks\logging.py", line 115, in on_train_begin
        self._offset = float(lines[-1].split(",")[0]) - time.time()
    ValueError: could not convert string to float:

(there's a change - from line 163 to line 160, but I think it shouldn't matter)
Oh, ok. Could you please attach the log file again?

@stanos4 did you reinstall schnetpack, after you made the changes in the CSV logger? If not, you might need to activate your environment, go to the schnetpack folder and run:

```
>>> pip uninstall schnetpack
>>> pip install .
```

This reinstalls schnetpack, which should include your changes.

I will give it a try tomorrow. However, I modified the "logging.py" file that was being used according to your patch (i.e. modifying single occurrence of file opening by passing the newline parameter), and upon restarting the python console it was still not working (modifying the same file by my "workaround" solves the error for me).

Hi, sorry it took me so long. I just checked out the current git repo and installed with "pip install .", but the same problem persists:

    trainer.train(device=device, n_epochs=n_epochs)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "C:\Users\ssimko\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\site-packages\schnetpack\train\trainer.py", line 160, in train
        h.on_train_begin(self)
      File "C:\Users\ssimko\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\site-packages\schnetpack\train\hooks\logging.py", line 115, in on_train_begin
        self._offset = float(lines[-1].split(",")[0]) - time.time()
    ValueError: could not convert string to float:
